text: Patient: This would be two. Doctor: Yeah. We’ll do three more of this um because again there’s a little interruption, there’s radiation, you know so we’ll just do four total Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Did you make a comment once that um that chemo doesn’t go up the skull or up to the brain or something like that? Doctor: It doesn’t typically penetrate to go to brain tissue, but it will penetrate to skull because that’s part of the bone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll target the area even though you had it radiated. It still would be going around Patient: Okay. Doctor: the neck. It just doesn’t go into the brain. Patient: I don’t want that to come back. Doctor: Yes, we don’t want it to come back either.

text: Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email-

text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process?

text: Family Member: Whew. Doctor: Number two. It’s a limited treatment meaning you’re only going to get three infusions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And how it works is we take blood out of him at the Red Cross. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They send it to Atlanta to kind of wake it up. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways.

text: Patient: So that would be something . Uh nutrition – Then I’m scheduled to speak with someone from a company out of Colorado called Doctor: Hmmmm Patient: Should I hold off on that during the period of treatment as well? Doctor: So, so, yes. Uhm um they have some things that interfere with what we do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so I’m you know all holistic approaches for all these things. I can tell you back in the day I wrote books about this stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can tell you that the most important thing you can do is not gain weight. You do not need a special diet; you do not need special things. What is important is you don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you stay physically active. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all that’s important because I mean what is bad is if you get fat, fat is a pro-inflammatory environment and people who do get fat die quicker from cancer. All cancers. Patient: Right.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
